loans.name: Rovelyn

texts.en:
Rovelyn C. is from the village of San Francisco, Cauayan City,Isabela. She is 31 years old. Rovelyn is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Rovelyn owns & operates a business raising livestock, primarily pigs, for fattening and sale. Rovelyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3200 PHP every time she sells one of her raised pigs.

In 2008, Rovelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rovelyn is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by Rovelyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Ol

texts.en: Mrs. Ol H. is a 27 year old married woman and she is a villager who lives in Tuol Kandal Tonle village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Pen Keo, are farmers who own 2-hectares of land to cultivate rice and they are also farmers who work very hard to support their family living. With the farm, they face a problem because they do not have enough money to support it. Thus, Mrs. Ol H. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer, rice see, and to pay for hire laborers to plow the farm and to pay for hirer farming laborers to cultivate rice. Aside from farmer, Mr. Pen Keo is also construction worker who is able to receive a little salary to hold up his family.  This couple has two children, one in a student and another one is 5 years old. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, rice see, and to pay for hire laborers to plow the farm and to pay for hirer farming laborers to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie M. is from the village of Villa Felipa, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 26 years old. Rosemarie is married. To make a living, Rosemarie owns & operates a business selling and renting DVD's and also selling electronic cell phone loads in all networks in the local community. Rosemarie has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 6500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rosemarie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rosemarie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Rosemarie is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Rosemarie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

loans.name: Em

In order to support the farm, she decided to ask for a loan to purchase a water machine and the rest of the loan she wants to buy fertilizer, pesticide and to pay for farming laborers. Aside from farmer, she is also Khmer noodle seller in the local market who is able to earn a small income to hold up her family living. Mrs. Em K. is widow with two children one is a farmer and another one is a student.

loans.name: Dante

texts.en:
" What you plant, you will harvest". That is being said by Dante M., who is from the village of Estefania, Amulung, Cagayan. He is 60 years old. Dante is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Dante owns & operates a business raising crops, primarily from planting & harvesting corn for sale. Dante has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 35000 PHP per harvest.

In 2007, Dante joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Dante has successfully repaid a previous loan  from ASKI. He is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Dante from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to his house.

loans.name: Tun

loans.name: Nagina Shamshad's Group

texts.en:
Nagina shamshad lives in a small city called Borewala in Pakistan. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. Her husband is a mason by profession.  To support him financially, his three sons are also involve in the same work and in this way they maximize their earning. They had to leave their education after eighth grade and started working to financially support their family.  

Nagina stays at home, manages the household chores and carries out her responsibilities as a housewife and a mother.  She has applied for a loan from Asasah to financially assist her husband who will buy masonary tools with the loan. With the help of a loan, her husband will be able to do his job better.  

Nagina  is a third year client of Asasah. Earlier she received a loan to help her children in starting their own businesses. They are now doing well. She repaid her loans on a timely basis, without any delay  and attended all the meetings with full responsibility.

loans.use: Purchase masonary tools

loans.name: Huy

N. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a new motorbike for her child to operat, making his business more efficient. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: 030635- Quang Trung - Hoang Thanh- Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en:
"N. Lường thị (03 06 087) was born in 1976 and lives in the town of Thôn Quang trung- Hoằng Thanh - Hoằng Hóa.  N. is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 030635-Quang Trung- Hoang Thanh (030635-Quang Trung- Hoang Thanh).


N. is married and has 2 school-aged children.  To making a living, N. owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising cattle for sale.  N. has been engaged in this business for over 4 years and earns approximately 800000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2006, N. joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  N. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3.079.800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase young livestock to raise & sell in future.  She is now requesting a new loan of 4248000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  The loan will be the 12th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  N. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Lê thị L. (77) is a 32 year-old female who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


2.  Lê thị T. (64) is a 48 year-old female who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.


3.  Hồ thị H. (107) is a 53 year-old female who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to support her business in the manufacturing sector operating a manufacturing business.


4.  Chu thị

loans.use: To purchase young livestock to raise & sell

loans.name: Jovinsol

texts.en:
Jovinsol C. is from the village of Brgy. Bonfal East, in Bayombong in the province of Nueva Vizcaya. He is 38 years old. Jovinsol is married and has three school-age children. To make a living, Jovinsol owns and operates a business raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from cultivating coconut trees and harvesting the fruit to sell. Jovinsol has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jovinsol joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovinsol has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to pay for services to increase crop yield. Jovinsol is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Jovinsol from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's general living conditions.

loans.name: Koem Nit

texts.en: Mrs. Koem Nit S., age 30, married woman and she is a villager who lives in Angk PraS. village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Bol Len, are farmers who own 3-hectares of land to cultivate rice. Aside from farmer, Mrs. Koem Nit S. is also pig breeder at home. With both of these occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. In order to support these both occupations, Mrs. Koem Nit S. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to cultivate rice and to piglets for breeding and pig food. This couple has a child, who is attending in the local school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to cultivate rice and to piglets for breeding and pig food

loans.name: Chay

texts.en: Chay S. is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. S. is a farmer, earning an income of US $2 per day. Her husband is a construction worker and earns an income of US $3 per day. S. is requesting a loan of US $700 to purchase a motorbike for family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a motorbike

loans.name: Torn

texts.en: Mrs. Torn K., age 59, and she is a villager who lives in Tuol Svay village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Chin Yim, are farmers who own 1.50-hectars of land to cultivate rice for a living. With the farm, they face a problem because they do not have enough money to support it. Thus, Mrs. Torn K. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide and to pay for hire laborers to plow her farm to cultivate rice. Aside from farmer, Mrs. Torn K. is also grocery seller in the local village that is able to earn a small income to support her family. This couple has three children; one is a seamstress in a garment factory and one is a grocery seller while the last one is a student.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and to pay for hire laborers to plow her farm to cultivate rice

loans.name: Ma

texts.en: Ma S., 55, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. S. and husband grow cucumbers and have a business providing ferry services, earning an income of US $3 each per day. S. is requesting a loan of US $1200 to repair their boat in order to operate their ferry business more efficiently. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: repair the ferry

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Shamim is a 39 years old lady who is very supportive for her family. She has applied for a loan to help her husband buy animals for his business
She lives in a city called Borewala with her husband and six children. Four of the children are getting their education while the other two are very young and have not started to attend school yet. 

Shamim supports her family financially by sewing. She takes orders from her neighborhood clients and fulfills them on time to make an income. 
Shamim’s husband has bought and sold animals for 20 years. She is hopeful that by investing money in his business, he will be able to earn more by purchasing animals in bulk.

loans.use: Purchase animals to resell

loans.name: Sari's Group

texts.en: Five people are made up a group loan and they live in Krang Touch village in Takeo province. Mrs. Sari P. is a group leader who was born in 1972, selected by the other members who will use portion of their loan for varied ways. She is a farmer who owns two point five-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family moreover she is also a pig breeder while her husband, Mr. Chork Suon, is a motorcycle taxi driver. Both of them do work a lot but they can earn a little income. So to improve their family living, Mrs. Sari P. is finding for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business. She is a mother of three children whom all are attending in local public school.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: 03.04.09-Hoang Thanh-Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en:
"Dai L. T. (100) is a 52 year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoa.  Dai is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 03.04.09-Lien Ha- Hoang Thanh-Hoang Hoa (03.04.09-Lien Ha- Hoang Thanh-Hoang Hoa).


Dai is married and has 3 adult-aged children.  To making a living, Dai operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  WhiL. not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising cattL. for saL..  Dai has been engaged in this business for over 20 years and earns approximately 700000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2004, Dai joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Dai has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3079800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase young livestock to raise & sell.  She is now requesting a new loan of 5000000 VND which will be used to purchase livestock, feed & other supplies.  The loan will be the 9th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Dai plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

5.  N. T. Lan (101) is a 25 year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

loans.name: Rani's Group

texts.en:
Rani lives in a city called Borewala in Pakistan with her family. Her husband is a daily wage labor and both his sons do the same work. The contractors hire them for periods of 15 to 20 days and give them the task of breaking bricks into pieces and also carring bricks. Her husband has tractor also with which he drives in the field to plow the land. 

Rani family is living in very poor financial condition as sometimes her husband and sons can get work and sometimes not. So, to financially support her husband, Rani makes and sells toys with which she earns a reasonable income. 

She has applied for a loan for the third time from Asasah for her husband. Rani is hoping that her family’s financial condition will get better with the help of a loan  they will be able tohave a better standard of life.

loans.name: Fuzlan's Group

texts.en:
Fuzlan lives in a small city in Pakistan called Borewala, which is famous for its shrines.  She is a young lady who is 29 years of age and the mother of five children. Two of her children are going to school while the others are very young.

Her husband is a laborer and also involved in an animal selling business as well.  He started this business 2 years ago by receiving a loan from Asasah and it proved to be a profitable one for him. Now he wants to buy buffalo which he will sell for profit.

Fuzalan has applied for a loan to financially assist her husband in expanding his animal selling business.  She is hopeful that this time her experience of receiving a loan will be good as well. 

In the previous two years she never gave any complaints to Asasah regarding repayments and attended meetings regularly.

Sim P., 31, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. P. is a construction worker earning an income of US $4 per day. Her husband is a barber, earning an income of US $5 per day to help cover the family expenses.

P. is requesting a loan of US $1,200 to buy a motorbike to transport fish and meat to sell in the village. In the future she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. texts.en: This village bank loan consists of twenty one people whom all have been selected Mrs. Choeung K. is a village bank president who was born in 1972 located in Ta Ei village in Takeo province. All the members will use portion of their loan for varied ways in which it can improve their businesses. Mrs. Choeung K. and her husband, Mr. Phoeurn Kory, are farmers who own a half-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family moreover her husband is also a construction worker. Their problem is that their field is infertile and it has a lot insect. So to improve production, Mrs. Choeung K. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline. She is a mother of five children, four of whom are studying in local public school and they all are helping their parents to do farming, while the other is five years old.

Mrs. Yom S. is a group leader who is 51-year-old, selected by the other members who will use portion of their loan in which it can improve their businesses in current year. She is a clothes seller door-to-door where she can earn some money to support her family. Since her business is going well she wants to expand. So to improve her face business, Mrs. Yom S. is asking for a loan to buy more clothes to resale. Her husband, Mr. Khom Gnen, is a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria E. is a 46-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating 2 business ventures: Food Vending and Video Rental businesses. She lives in Kapusu-an, Poblacion, Sibonga, Cebu. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her Food Vending and Video Rental businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 7000. 

Victoria is now borrowing PHP 16000 to add to her business capital.  This will be her 6th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 16000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Victoria aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way. 

In the accompanying picture Victoria had already sold all of the food she prepared to sell for the day!

About NWTF:In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital for her food sales and video rental business

loans.name: Sabra's Group

texts.en:
Sabra is the wife of M. H. and lives in a city called Borewala in Pakistan. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. 

A very talented lady, Sabra owns & operates a clothes-sewing business. She does this work for the purpose of meeting financial expenses. Her clientele base is her neighbors. She charges them reasonably for her work, which enables them to come again to her for sewing their clothes. 

Her husband operates a grocery shop in the community. He has been operating it for 3 years. He has good recognition among the people. He tries to fulfill their needs on timely basis, but now he has little stock to enable him to meet any needs of his customers. This affects his ability to further sell and meet his customers' needs. Therefore, Sabra has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount he will buy the necessary groceries, which helps him to maintain his customers by fulfilling their needs. 

Sabra has given birth to five children: two daughters and three sons. She has enrolled all of them in a school so they get the education to make their futures bright. 

She is a second-year member of Asasah. In her first year she managed good credit behavior and attended the meetings regularly.

loans.use: to purchase groceries for her husband's grocery shop

loans.name: Uldarico J.

texts.en:
Uldarico J. T. is from the village of Balide Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. He is 46 years old. Uldarico J. is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Uldarico J. owns & operates a business venture in the food sector, operating a restaurant. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from serving a variety of different meals to customers in the local community. Uldarico J. has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Uldarico J joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Uldarico J. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Uldarico J. is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Uldarico J. from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Bushra is 30 years old, married, and a mother of two daughters. They all live in a city called Borewala in Pakistan. Borewala City is famous for its shrines.

Her husband's name is Z. I., and he is involved in a clothes-selling business. He purchased clothes from different cities, Faisalabad and Lahore (famous for its textiles), and sells in the local markets. He has been doing this work for over two years.

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent has been operating his mixed farm for the last ten years in the outskirts of Litein Town in Rift Valley, Kenya. His farm produces pineapples, coffee, tea, milk and maize, which he sells locally. He has also employed a farmhand from his community.

Vincent is 50 years old and married with 6 children, ages ranging between 7 and 18. All the children are currently attending school. He solely depends on the income from his farming activities to cater to the basic needs of the family. He however faces the challenge of drought, which affects his produce and the poor road network.

Vincent has a clean record with Juhudi Kilimo after he successfully completed his previous loan of KES.45,000. He has requested this loan of KES.60,000 to purchase a dairy cow. He believes that with this loan, he will be able to generate more income for the family through the sale of milk, and this will improve their living standards and help pay school fees.

He would like to stock more quality dairy cows in future. He appreciates Juhudi's efforts of not just availing loans but also caring about the social being of the clients.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

Bienvenido P. is from the village of Mangcuram. He is 59 years old. Bienvenido is married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Bienvenido owns and operates a business raising crops, specifically, planting and harvesting corn for sale. Bienvenido has been in business for more than 40 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Bienvenido joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bienvenido has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Bienvenido is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Bienvenido from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

To make a living, Norma owns and operates a business providing motorcycle transportation services. Norma has been in business for more than two years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Norma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Norma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Norma from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Osinasio Omongini

texts.en:
Osinasio Omongini O. is a married man with seven children and he is 68 years of age. Initially, he was a farmer, which he realized could not meet the needs of his family effectively. After retiring from his employment in 2002, he started a poultry farming business in Malanga to generate income in order to sustain his family. He often travels after every six months to Nambale for additional stocks. 

He would wish to expand his business to generate more income. He has since applied for a loan worth Ksh.10,000, that he will use to boost his farming business and fulfill his dream of affording a quality education for his children in the future.

loans.use: To boost his poultry farming business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Solomon

texts.en:
Solomon O. Is a cereal vendor, a business he started in 1994, in Nambale, Busia. Owing to his family's needs, Solomon realized that he could not depend only on the salary from his employment alone, and needed to start this venture to enable him get enough income to sustain his family basic necessities. 

He normally travels to Busia twice a week to purchase more inventory because of the high demand of the products. His dream of diversifying his business could not be realized, and for this reason, he joined K-MET micro finance initiative to access a loan worth Kshs 10,000 to enable him increase his inventory to boost his income. He is 56 years old, married and the father of ten children.

loans.use: Increase inventory

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en: Mrs. Thoeun K., age 46, and she is a villager who lives in Angk Trav village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice for a living. Her husband, Mr. Sophat Prum, is a bike cycle repair and also furniture maker such as (table, chair, door, ---) for selling. With their occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support the family. For her husband furniture making, Mrs. Thoeun K. decided to ask for a loan to purchase metals to support her husband furniture making. This couple has a child, who is a student in the local school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To purchase metals to support her husband furniture making.

loans.name: Scolastica Makokha

texts.en:
Scolastica Makokha M. is a widow, age 45, and a proud mother of two children. She started a mini shop business in Nambale Busia in 2008, in order to generate income. 

Before this venture, she used to practice farming for commercial purposes, but owing to the death of her husband, she could not get substantial income to support the needs of her family. She often travels three times per week to Nambale for additional inventory. Having heard about KIVA/KMET loans and how it has changed the lives of many, she decided to apply for a loan Kshs. 10,000 to enable her to boost her business and revive her farming activities, so that she gets enough income that will enable her to meet her future goal of educating her children.

loans.use: To boost her business and be able to revive her farming business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Norita

texts.en:
Norita is a hardworking businesswoman who has a food vending business to earn a better living. She has been in this business for more than 20 years. Norita belongs to a group of young entrepreneurs of Riverside Center in Rizal West Branch (RWB). With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders of her previous loan, Norita appreciates that the loan has helped her improve own business, build her own house and support the education of her siblings, hence having better living standards. 

Currently in Norita’s increasing business, she would like to request a second kiva loan in a much larger loan amount to supplement her running capital. Specifically, the loan fund will be used to pay for more inventory for her business, including coconut jam, banana chips, peanut butter, barquillos (wafers), banana fritters, immature rice (pinipig), cashew nuts and other supplies. In the meantime, the profits she makes from her business are saved in preparation for the expense of educating her four children. She hopes that until their graduation from college, she will be able to give them her support financially. 

Norita dreams to have a store in the marketplace and to buy more inventory in the future for better output. She sees herself venturing into a full-fledged wholesale business in the next seven years. With the support of our Kiva supporters, Norita is optimistic that the family business will continue to grow, bring steady profits, and sustain improvements in her family’s quality of life. Her long term goals are to maintain the output of her business, and support the other family business of rental fees (apartment houses) in the local community, and to purchase a new tricycle (three-wheeled-vehicles) for added income. Norita also dreams of brighter future and to bring happiness and harmony into their home.

loans.use: To buy inventory for her business, including coconut jam, banana chips, peanut butter, wafers, banana fritters, cashew nuts, immature rice and other supplies

loans.name: Caroline Akinyi

texts.en:
Caroline Akinyi W., who has been a housewife for a considerable duration of time, testifies how, at times, life can be hard with only the husband being the breadwinner. For this reason, she started selling cereals in Nambale, Busia, in 2007, to earn income and become economically independent. She often purchases her inventory on weekly basis from Busia, and, with the profit earned, she has been able to support her husband in taking care of the family's needs.

She would wish to expand her business and be able to buy a pick-up to help in transporting her farm supplies, and having heard about KIVA/KMET loans, she decided to apply for Ksh.10,000 to boost her business. She is 32 years old, married, and the mother of two children, and lives in Nambale.

loans.use: Increase her inventory

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Fransisca Odongo

texts.en: Fransisca Odongo N.  is 30 years old. She is married and the mother of ten children. She has been carrying out commercial farming activities to support her family. Due to the farming's low income, she decided to start a fish vending business in 2005, in Nambale, Busia, to get adequate income to provide for her family's needs. This move has caused her to travel to Nambale town monthly to purchase more inventory to enable her to meet the demands of her customers. To diversify this business, she applied for a loan worth Kshs. 10,000 to boost her business, so as to get a substantial income that will help to fulfill her future dreams of buying cattle and leading a comfortable life.

loans.use: Expand business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mirembe Kikooza Development Group-Mukono

texts.en: It has been four years since N. Annet, age 34, began her food sales business in Kikooza-Mukono. With profits from this business, she has catered to her family's needs to the fullest. She attributes her business' longevity to her good relationship skills, especially when transacting business with her clients. Her main challenges have manifested themselves mostly during the rainy seasons, when prices of most of her cash crops fluctuate. In a week, she makes profits to the sum of 100,000 shillings. With this loan, she wants to buy in bulk more profitable agri-produce like cassava, maize and coffee, that she will later resell.

loans.use: The purchase of more profitable cash crops, like coffee and cassava, that she will resell

loans.name: Antonina Narotso

texts.en:
Antonina Narotso M. has been selling food items in Nambale, Busia, since 2006, to generate income after the death of her husband. Before that, she used to be a farmer, though it could not give her enough income to support her family size of six children. 

To enhance the effective running of her business, Antonina normally travels to Nambale town on a daily basis to buy more inventory, so as to ensure adequate supply of commodities for her customers. She intends to expand her business. For this reason, she requested a loan worth Kshs 10,000 through Kiva. She believes this is a an idea that will help her to make more profits, which she will be able to save to enlarge her investment and buy livestock. She is 40 years old and lives in Lwanyange.

loans.use: To expand her business

Owing to the meager income which she was getting from her employment in a beauty salon, she decided to set up her own salon early 2010 in Nambale Busia. She decided that she could earn considerably more income and assist her husband in taking care of the family. She travels to Nairobi to purchase her supplies and wishes to expand her business. She would like to get a loan of Kshs. 10000 to boost her business. This woul enable her to earn considerable more ncome to support her family and start a hair dressing school.

loans.use: To increase her business

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet has been enjoying spending the profits from her fish-selling business. Because of this, she has able to sustain the needs of her four children and has been able to make their lives quite a bit improved. With that, Juliet is encouraged to work harder and aim further for her business and family because she has her own business to support their financial needs and loans she can access to support her business. Therefore, Juliet wants to take this opportunity to grow her business by requesting another loan of 14,000 Philippine pesos from Kiva lenders for additional business capital. Juliet wants to buy more fish to sell and attract more clients.

Her long-term goals are to have a successful fish-selling business, funding the college education of her four siblings and supporting her family financially.  With the support of Kiva lenders, she is determined to achieve business success with her new entrepreneurial endeavor. Juliet’s wish to give her children a better life fuels her commitment to her enterprise.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell and attract more clients

loans.name: Pedrito

texts.en:
Pedrito L. is from the village of Estefania, Amulung, Cagayan. He is 30 years old. Pedrito is married and has 2 infant-aged children. To make a living, Pedrito owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting corn for sale. Pedrito has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 50000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Pedrito joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pedrito has successfully repaid a previous loan of 33,000 PHP from ASKI. Pedrito is requesting a new loan of 33000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Pedrito from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Kea

texts.en: Mrs. Kea Y., age 48, and is a villager who lives in Krang Touch village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Chantha Out, are farmers who own 2.50-hectare of land to cultivate rice for a living. . The farm's soil is now infertile and there is not enough water to irrigate the crops. Thus, Mrs. Kea Y. decided to ask for a loan to buy a water machine and to buy fertilizer, pesticide and rice seed to cultivate rice. Aside from farmers, she is also pig breeder at home and her husband is a house constructor. With their occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. This couple has four children, one is a farmer and the other three are students and also help their parents with the farming.

loans.use: to buy a water machine and to buy fertilizer, pesticide and rice seed to cultivate rice

loans.name: Lea

texts.en:
Lea D. is from the village of Brgy. Lantap, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 31 years old and single. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Lea has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Lea joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lea has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lea is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This loan will be the fifth loan Lea has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the increased inventory to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offerings

loans.name: Yeng

texts.en: Mrs. Yeng D., age 43, and is a villager who lives in Prey Rumpeak village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Chorn Neang, are farmers who own 10-hectares of land to cultivate rice. With the farm, they face a problem because they do not have enough money to support it. Thus Mrs. Yeng D. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to cultivate rice and to buy pig food for pig breeding. Aside from farmers, they are also having a rice mill machine at home for hire to the villager for the profit and they are also rice wine maker and pig breeder at home. With these occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. This couple has five children, four are students and and also help their parents with the businesses while another age 4, is not yet in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to cultivate rice and to buy pig food for pig breeding.

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en: Mrs. Sopheap O., 39, and she is a villager who lives in Prey Rumpeak village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Nob Toem, are farmers who own 4-hectares of land to cultivate rice. For this farm, Mrs. Sopheap O. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, to pay for hire laborers to plow the farm and she wants use the rest of the loan to buy piglets for breeding and pig food. Aside from farmers, her husband is also Khmer cake seller in the local market who can earn a small income to improve his family living. This couple has six children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory and four are students also help their parents with the farming while a youngest one too young.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, to pay for hire laborers to plow the farm and she wants use the rest of the loan to buy piglets for breeding and pig food.

loans.name: Pepita

texts.en:
Pepita C. is from the village of Villa Felipa, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 66 years old, widowed, and has 6 adult-aged children. To make a living, Pepita owns and operates a business making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling native delicacies like suman, or sweetened rice wrapped in banana leaves, in the local community. Pepita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Pepita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Pepita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Pepita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the second loan Pepita has taken out from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

Melanie B. is from the village of Brgy. Lantap, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 29 years old, married, and has 2 infants. To make a living, Melanie owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Melanie has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Melanie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melanie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Melanie is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This loan will be the fifth loan Melanie has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Mrs. Chan D., 47 years old and is a villager who lives in Prey Chheu Teal village, Takeo province. She and her husband are farmers who own 2-hectares of land to cultivate rice and this spouse is also works very hard with their farm to support their family. Aside from farmers, they are also pig breeders at home. With both of these occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. In order to support their both of occupation, Mrs. Chan D. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and to pay for hire laborer to plow the farm to cultivate rice and to buy two piglets for breeding and pig food. This couple has three children, one is a seamstress in a garment factory, and the other two are students in the local school

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and to pay for hire laborer to plow the farm to cultivate rice and to buy two piglets for breeding and pig food.

loans.name: Hope Foundation, Kyenjojo Group

texts.en:
John Mary K. is very hard working and ambitious about owning a big agricultural farm in his home area of Buhihi Kyenjojo. Yet he is in circumstances that may make him seem like a wishful thinker. This means he faces long odds in achieving that mission. He, however, has at length built a strong determination that has played in his favor.

With strong hard working skills up his sleeve, he has carved out a dependable business selling bananas, farming poultry and growing fruit. John Mary has banked on this business for the last 3 years and his family of six children has also enjoyed the good graces that have come with that business. He earns monthly profits of 250,000 Ugandan shillings. With this loan he hopes to purchase mulches and fertilizers to help improve his agricultural farm and also buy pesticides, as pests like banana weevils have always affected the plantation and reduced yields. This will in turn improve his yields, and hence his sales revenue, and will enable him to live a more satisfying life.

loans.use: purchase of mulches and pesticides for his agricultural farm improvement.

loans.name: Saroeurn

texts.en: Mr. Saroeurn B., age 40, and is a villager who lives in Sam raong village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 1.50-hectares of land to cultivate rice for a living. In order to support this farm, Mr. Saroeurn B. decided to ask for a loan to buy an ox to add her old one to cultivate rice. And side from farmer, she is also pig breeder at home. Her husband, Mr. Nhy Koem, is a motorbike taxi driver, who is able to earn a small income to support his family. This couple has four children, who all are students and also help their mother on the farm. His wife is in the picture with him.

loans.use: To buy an ox to add her old one to cultivate rice

loans.name: Chroeb

texts.en: Mrs. Chroeb M., 39, and is a villager who lives in Krang Touch village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 3.80-hectares of land to cultivate rice for a living and aside from farmer she is also pig breeder at home. In order to support this both or occupations, Mrs. Chroeb M. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to cultivate rice and to buy two mother pigs for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Khen Khon, is a horse cart driver, who is able to earn a small income to support his family. This couple has four children; one is a seamstress in a garment factory and two are attend in the local school while the youngest one is, age 4, and is not yet in school

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to cultivate rice and to buy two mother pigs for breeding.

loans.name: Marivic

Marivic C. is from the village of Villa Felipa, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 33 years old, married, and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Marivic owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Marivic has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 8500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marivic joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marivic has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Marivic is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the third loan Marivic has taken out from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

loans.name: Mom

texts.en: Mrs. Mom P., age 38, and she is a villager who lives in Prey Preal village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 1-hectare of land to cultivate rice for a living. Her husband, Mr. Bros Soung is a rice wine maker and also helps his wife on the farm. With both of these occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. In order to increase income to improve the family, Mrs. Mom P. decided to ask for a loan to buy six piglets for breeding and pig food. This couple has four children, who all are students and also support their parents businesses. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy six piglets for breeding and pig food.

loans.name: Esmenia

texts.en:
Esmenia D. C. is from the city of Rizal Santiago. She is 54 years old. Esmenia is married and has nine adult children. Esmenia owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Esmenia has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 2,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2010, Esmenia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Esmenia is requesting her first loan, for 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia F. is from the town of Dumabel Aglipay Quirino. She is 45 years old. Leticia is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Leticia owns & operates a business growing fruits and vegetables. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale. Leticia has been engaged in her business for over 18 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2009, Leticia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from ASKI, which was for 5,000 PHP and was used purchase additional products to sell.

Leticia is now requesting her second loan from ASKI, for 7,000 PHP, which will be used to to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Sourn

texts.en:
Sourn C., 55, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, an area known for being the most populated part of the country. C. is a food seller, earning an income of $7 US per day. Her husband is in the military, earning an income of $6 per day. 

C. is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase supplements to expand the food selling business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy more supplements to expand a food selling business

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen is optimistic that her sewing business will produce steady income to improve her economic stability and her family’s quality of life.  Her long term dreams are to continue supporting her children’s education and to have a successful tailoring shop someday. Helen would like to receive a loan to purchase inventory to continue her sewing business, including fabric cottons and other materials needed in her business.  As a member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, Helen is thankful for access to loans to support her dreams.

loans.use: fabric cottons and other materials

loans.name: Maren

texts.en: Mrs. Maren M., age 28, married woman and is a villager who lives in Prey Sbat village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Saophorn Thok, is a carpenter. With both of these occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family.  In order to increase income to improve the family living, Mrs. Maren M. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow and piglets for breeding and pig food. This couple has two children, who all are too young and are not yet in school.

loans.use: to buy a cow and piglets for breeding and pig food.

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Lun T., 47, is married and resides with his wife and four children in Battambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality rice products. T. is an ice-cream seller, earning a gross income of $30 US per day. His wife is a grocery seller, earning an income of $7 per day. 

T. is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase a new motorbike to operate his business more efficiently. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house.  This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a motorbike

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en: Marilou C. is from the village of Barangay 25, Pandan, Gingoog City. She is 34 years old. Marilou is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Marilou runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food, daily-use products and rice by the kilo. Marilou has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 6,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. Marilou has been selling household products since buying and selling fish failed to give enough profits as her family is growing and their needs are more than they have been used to. In 2009, Marilou joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilou has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marilou is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Marilou from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. loans.name: Sourn

texts.en:
Sourn S., 37, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Battambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality rice products. 

S. is a grocery seller, earning an income of $4 per day. Her husband is a duck raiser, earning an income of $7 per day. S. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase more ducks for her husband to raise. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. 

This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: Buy ducks to raise

loans.name: Kyenjojo Disabled, Kyenjojo Group

texts.en:
A transparent and very hardworking Robinah K., aged 50 years, is a married mother of eight children. She operates a retail shop, selling general merchandise for home use like plastics, basins, jerrycans, cups, salt, soap and more, from Rwamukora, Kyenjojo town. She started this business five years ago and at the end of every month, she is able to pocket profits to the tune of 200,000 Ugandan shillings. 

Her main drawback has been having a small amount of stock that cannot match the purchasing rate of the customers. Robinah is therefore seeking a loan that she figures will help her stock more goods that will satisfy the customers’ high demand and also transform her enterprise into a big enterprise as she looks at opening up more branches. 

Being very committed to the business with good customer care, she hopes to increase her sales revenue. This will bring about a transformation of her business and enable her to achieve a self-sustaining life and cater to her family requirements, especially fulfilling her dream of educating her children to higher levels.

Robinah K. appears at the top left corner in the small photo and she also appears in the big group photo.

loans.use: Purchase more stock of goods like basins, jerrycans, cups, salt and soap for her shop.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Mrs. Pov Y.,age 27, married woman and is a villager who lives in Phngeas village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr.Nob Thou, are farmer who own 3-hectares of land to cultivate rice. For this farm, Mrs. Pov Y. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide to cultivate rice and to buy piglets for breeding. With both of these occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. Aside from farmer,Mr.Nob Thou is also cow middleman who is able to earn a small income to hold up his family. This couple has two children, who all are too young and are not yet in school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide to cultivate rice and to buy piglets for breeding

loans.name: Chheang

texts.en: Chheang S., 40, is married and lives with her husband and a child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia – an area known for quality palm products. S. is a grocer, earning a gross income of $20 US per day. Her husband raises pigs and earns $8 US per day. S. is requesting a loan of $700 US to purchase a motorbike to transport groceries to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita A. owns and operates a sari-sari (variety retail shop) selling both food and daily use products in her community. She changed her business from buying and selling fish to retailing different household products because she is trying to have a business which will generate more income. She is 54 years old, married and has four school-age children. They are from the village of Barangay 25, Pandan, Gingoog City. Teresita has been in her business for more than a year and earns approximately 8,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Teresita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be her fourth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. loans.name: Raheela Shoqat's Group

texts.en:
Raheela shoqat is 30 years of age, married and a mother of three children: two boys and one girl. All of her children are getting an education; two are in kindergarten and one is in 1st standard. A very caring lady, Raheela stays at home, manages the household chores and takes care of her family. She has completed her education through 8th standard and couldn’t study further due to her family's poor financial condition. She has decided that the same destiny will never befall her children; that’s why she is focusing on their studies and giving them a good educational base.
  
Raheela's husband, N. S., is a rickshaw driver. He earns 300 PKR per day and 15,000 PKR on a monthly basis. Raheela has applied for her 4th loan from Asasah for her husband. He will use the loan to repair his rickshaw and improve his working conditions.

By being with Asasah for last three years. Raheela has become a regular client. Each year, she has maintained a good credit record and attended all meetings regularly.

loans.use: Repair a rickshaw

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes A. is from the village of Consuelo, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 60 years old, widowed and has 5 adult-aged children. Lourdes owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily native delicacies such as sweetened rice and banana cubes and sweet potato cubes, in the local community. Lourdes has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Lourdes joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lourdes has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Lourdes is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Lourdes from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Parveen Akhtar's Group

texts.en:
Parveen akhtar is 43 years old, married and the mother of three children. They live in the city of Borewala, which is famous for its shrines. A very talented lady, Parveen is involved in a domestic-sewing business while her husband, M. akram, is a driver. To help support them financially, their elder son runs an electric supplies shop. Their younger son is in 9th standard and their daughter is in 12th standard. 

The elder son, M. A., stayed in school until 10th standard and then started working. He has been in this business for the last 6 years. Parveen has applied for a loan from Asasah for her son, who will use the loan amount to buy electrical supplies such as wires, tube lights and switches in bulk and enhance his business.

loans.use: Purchase electrical supplies

loans.name: Marina

texts.en: Marina A. is currently in the business of selling clothes and bedsheets at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock more bedsheets and some saddles to sell. Marina is 39 years old and married to a businessman. She has 2 children, who both attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a departmental store.

loans.use: Stock more bedsheets and some saddles to sell

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is grateful for access to loans and other services such as savings and insurance. With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, Erlinda is hopeful that her sewing business endeavor will provide steady income and improvements in her family’s quality of life.

Erlinda’s sewing business requires more capital to sustain its operation. Therefore, she has requested a loan through ASHI to support her business and to meet her customers' demands. Erlinda’s dreams are for her three children to complete college. Additionally, she hopes to continue her business as a sustainable livelihood to support her family. Through the support of ASHI and KIVA, she hopes to see herself and her family someday change their standard of living and move away from the ties of poverty.

loans.use: To support her sewing business

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia is M. I.'s wife and lives in the city of Borewala in Pakistan. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. A very caring lady, Razia stays at home managing the household chores and taking care of her family. She gets up early in the morning to prepare breakfast for them to send them to work with a healthy meal. At first, her husband was involved selling fruit but now their son has joined him in the business. Together, they earn a good income with profit. 

Razia has applied for a second loan from Asasah for her family business. With the loan, her husband will buy fruit in bulk and they will both increase their income.

Note: In this photo, her group member, Saima, is showing her clothes-sewing business.

loans.use: To purchase fruits to sell

loans.name: Morm

texts.en: Morm C., 54, is married and lives with her husband and six children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia – an area known for quality palm products. C. is a housewife while her husband is a taxi driver earning $8 US per day. C. is requesting a loan of $500 US to purchase car tires to replace the old ones to improve her husband’s business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda D. is from the village of Brgy.Lantap, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 41 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Yolanda owns and operates a general store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Yolanda has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from it.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Hanifan's Group

texts.en:
Hanifan is M. A. S.'s wife and they live in a city called Borewala in Pakistan. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. 
They are parents of three children: one son and two daughters, who are of different ages. The son is 25 years old, the elder daughter is 19 years old and the younger daughter is 16 years old. Their son is a carpenter and makes furniture on order. The elder daughter has a business sewing clothes and the younger daughter makes decorative embroidery on dresses to order. In this way, they all manage the financial expenses of their family. They are good at their work and also doing well with their businesses.  

Hanifan has applied for a loan for her nephew, who also lives with them. With the loan, he will buy bicycle spare parts for his spare parts shop and enhance his business. 

Hanifan is a second year member of Asasah. She maintained a good credit record last year and never missed a single meeting. 

Note: In this photo, Hanifan is showing her younger daughter's embroidery works.

loans.name: Annonciatha

Annonciatha needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company. This loan will allow her to expand her business by purchasing different cosmetic goods and different sizes of modern clothes. With the use of this loan, Annonciatha will hopefully earn more profits which, in turn, will be used for reinvestment as well as for better financial stability.

loans.name: 04.01.04 Hai Son - Hoang Truong Group

texts.en:
Hồng Đỗ thị is a 23 year-old woman living in the town of Hoang Hoa - Thanh Hoa.  Hồng is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 04.01.04 Hai Son - Hoang Truong.

Hồng is married and has 1 infant. She operates a family member's fishing business primarily harvesting and selling wild-caught fish in the local community. Hồng has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2010, Hồng joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hồng is requesting a new loan of 3,079,800 VND which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Hồng from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions/

Bình is married and has four grown-up children. Bình has been in this business for over 33 years and earns approximately 1,500,000 dong (VND) a month.

Bình has successfully repaid a previous loan of 597,000 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women which was used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. She is now requesting a new loan of 3,079,800 VND which will be used to purchase more fishing equipment including hooks and nets. This will be her third loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Bình plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

Bình is the leader of a seven member group accessing a loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members, if someone is delinquent or defaults. loans.name: Ronalyn

texts.en:
Ronalyn B. is 33 years old, married and has four school-aged children. She is from the village of Tinabalan outside of Gingoog City in Northern Mindanao. Ronalyn owns and operates a mini-restaurant from which she serves a variety of different meals to customers from the local community. Ronalyn has been in business for over four years and earns approximately 6500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Ronalyn joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from HSPFI which she used to renovate the business. Ronalyn is requesting a new loan, her third from HSPFI, of 9000 PHP to be used for business supplies and working capital. She plans to use any additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.
