loans.name: Seivwa

texts.en:
Seivwa R. is currently in the business of selling dried fish and tomatoes under a big tree near her home. She is requesting a loan to stock onions and cooking oil to sell.  

Seivwa is 42 years old and married to a peasant. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: Stock onions and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Kaija Abagambakamu, Mubende Group

texts.en:
As they say that determination leads to destiny, Benezel N. is gaining momentum in his charcoal-selling business at Kyegegwa in Mubende. Many people tend to undermine casual work here in Uganda, but the 48-year-old married father of nine children has been able to earn a living through that business for five years. 

Charcoal is commonly used here in Uganda as a form of energy in many homes to cook food and for housewarming in cold places, as prices for paraffin, gas and electricity are always high. Through the selling of charcoal, he is able to earn 70,000 Ugandan shillings as monthly profits, although it still has its drawbacks, like transporting his products to bigger markets like Kampala city. With this loan, he hopes to expand into bigger markets and supply to larger charcoal markets, as the loan will help pay for his transportation. This will help in improving his sales revenue to cater to his big family’s needs.

loans.use: Help with the transportation of charcoal to bigger markets

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en: Marilyn B. is from the village of Tinabalan, Gingoog City. She is 45 years old. Marilyn is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Marilyn makes and sells food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 6,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. Marilyn is the one who manages the small stall, while her husband is the baker. In 2009, Marilyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the third loan taken out by Marilyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About HSPFI HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en: Lucia A. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs at a restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice, baking flour and local Sudanese beans (ful). Lucia is 40 years old and married to a police officer. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant and purchase more tables and chairs for better accommodation.

loans.use: Stock more bags of rice, baking flour and local Sudanese beans

loans.name: Frederic

texts.en:
Frederic is 25 years old and is married with two children who are 1 and 2 years old. Frederic lives by sewing different styles of clothes and this is his 5th successful year in this business. He operates his business from morning until late in the afternoon hours.

Frederic needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a. to purchase four sewing machines and some clothing items. Thus, he will create four jobs for the people in his community.

By expanding his business and adding more equipment and workers, Frederic will hopefully earn more profits and these profits will allow him to create other areas of the same business. In addition, he and his family, will get their own shelter.

loans.use: To purchase four sewing machines and some clothing items

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary J. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol (siko) and beer at a bar and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell. Mary is 45 years old and widowed. She has seven children and three of her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build another bar in a different location.

loans.use: Stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama A. prepares corn dough for sale at Elmina. To prepare her corn dough she soaks her corn in a lot of water to get it soft. She then mills it and mixes it to form dough and leaves it for some hours before beginning to sell it.

Ama is a widow and she has no educational background. Her loan will be used to buy more maize to prepare corn dough for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To buy more maize to prepare corn dough for sale

loans.name: Duyen

texts.en:
Duyen T. D. is 23 years old and is married. She lives in Luc Canh village with her husband and her two children who are going to school.

Duyen T. D. sells pork in the market and, beside that, she grows rice. She has had this job for three years and earns a monthly income of about 4,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND).

Duyen T. D. has participated in SEDA since 2006. For her last loan, she borrowed 5,014,000 VND and has completely repaid this amount punctually. For this loan, she would like to borrow 8,502,000 VND to expand her business.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Clementine

texts.en:
Clementine is 35 years old and is married. She earns her living by selling a variety of new women’s shoes. She has been in this business for about ten years and the hours of her business are from 7 a.m. to 9 p.m.

Clementine needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a. She really hopes that it will allow her to expand her business through purchasing different sizes of shoes for sale. If successful, she will also start selling wholesale.

Through accessing this loan, Clementine has a hope of a better future for her business as well as for her family.

loans.use: To purchase different sizes of shoes to sell

loans.name: Lan

texts.en:
Lan T. Q. N. is 51 years old and lives in Luc Canh village with her husband and her two children.

Mrs Lan not only grows rice but also makes and sells paper clothes and paper furniture (people usually buy them to burn for the dead). She has a monthly income of about 5,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND) and has had this business for fifteen years.

Mrs Lan has participated in SEDA since 2006. For her last loan, she borrowed 5,014,000 VND and has completely repaid this amount punctually. For this loan, she would like to borrow 8,502,000 VND to buy more paper and goods to sell.

loans.use: To buy more paper and goods to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Srean Phin Village Bank Group

texts.en: In Tuol Sang Ka village, Takeo province consists of eighteen people who are made up a village bank loan. Mrs. Srean P. is a village bank president who was born in 1981, selected by the other members who will use portion of their loan for varied goals. She is a farmer who owns one-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family living. Now she has a problem because her field is infertile soil. So to improve production, Mrs. Srean P. is asK. for a loan to buy fertilizer. Her husband, Mr. Phroeurn Souy, is a horse cart diver. She is a mother of a child who is six years old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama A. N. is married to a mason and has two children. She has been through senior high school.

Ama prepares kenkey for sale (fermented corn dough, wrapped in corn or baN. leaves) as well selling salt in Elmina. She has been selling salt and kenkey for ten years. Ama uses her income to support her husband in providing food, clothing and shelter for her family.

Ama will use the loan to purchase more corn to prepare kenkey and more salt to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to save to build a storehouse for her salt.

loans.use: To purchase more corn to prepare kenkey and more salt to sell

loans.name: Hai's Group

texts.en:
Hai T. H. is 34 years old and is married with two children who are going to school. She not only grows rice and vegetables but also sells vegetables in the markets. She has operated this business for eight years and has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND).

Hai T. H. has participated in SEDA since 2006. For her last loan, she borrowed 4,578,000 VND and has completely repaid this amount punctually. For this loan, she would like to borrow 7,630,000 VND to invest in her small business.

About the other client borrowing money with her:

Thao T. P. is 29 years old and has a monthly income of about 2,500,000 VND. She wants to borrow 7,630,000 VND to breed poultry.

loans.use: To invest in her small business

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Ly T. D. is 43 years old and has two children who are going to school. Her husband is a worker. They have a monthly income of about 4,000,000 VND.

Mrs Ly breeds pigs and poultry and wants to expand her livestock, so she borrowed from SEDA. She has participated in SEDA since 2007. For her last loan, she borrowed 5,014,000 VND and has completely repaid this amount punctually. For this loan, she would like to borrow 7,630,000 VND to buy feed for her pigs and her poultry.

loans.use: To buy feed for her pigs and her poultry

loans.name: Theresah

texts.en:
Theresah K. prepares kenkey to sell in Elmina. To prepare her kenkey, she buys maize from the market and soaks it in enough water to soften it. She washes it on the third day and sends it to the mill to be milled. She then makes a mixture of dough from the milled wet corn and leaves it to prove (ferment and rise).

On the next day she divides the proved dough into two, uses one part for her firm half-cooked dough (she mixes it with water to get it in a porridge form and cooks it for some time to get a firm mixture or texture) and mixes the rest of the uncooked dough with the half-cooked dough. She moulds it into balls and wraps the balls in corn husk. She then cooks them again until they become soft enough to eat.

Kenkey can be eaten with various kinds of sauces such as pepper sauce with fried or roasted fish, roasted chicken, roasted turkey and any other kind of meat or fish.

Theresah has not received any form of education. She is married and has five dependents and supports her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more corn to prepare kenkey to sell to her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To buy more corn to prepare kenkey to sell

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama A. is married and has six dependents. Her husband is a welder. She has no formal education.

Ama sells foodstuffs in Elmina and has been in this trade for five years now. She uses her income to help her husband in taking care of the family. Ama will add the loan to her initial capital to purchase more vegetables and foodstuffs for sale and distribution.

With the new profits from her expanded business, Ama plans to provide a meaningful education to her children.

loans.use: To add to her initial capital to purchase more vegetables and foodstuffs for sale and distribution

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia D. is married and has six dependents. She has been through junior high school. Her husband is a security man.

Sophia sells varieties of raw rice at Elmina and uses her income to support her husband in taking care of her family. She will add the loan to her original capital to purchase extra bags of rice to sell.

With the new profits from her extended business, Sophia plans to save to build a storehouse for her goods.

loans.use: To purchase extra bags of rice to sell

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has one child, who is not in school. Jane has a business of selling charcoal, which she has had for two years. To help expand her business, Jane is requesting a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda, a Kiva partner. The loan will be used to buy more charcoal. Jane hopes that the loan will help her by allowing her to expand her business. In the future, Jane hopes to make her business international. About BRAC Uganda: This loan is administered by BRAC Uganda, a registered non-governmental organization (NGO) in Uganda that is also a part of the BRAC international network. BRAC Uganda attempts to address poverty through a holistic model, offering programs in education, health, water and sanitation, agriculture, and microfinance. BRAC Uganda’s microfinance program aims to provide the poor with easy, reliable and efficient access to institutional financial services, and reaches more than 150,000 families in Uganda. For more on BRAC Uganda, please see our partner page at http://www.kiva.org/partners/65, and join our lending team, Friends of BRAC Uganda, at http://www.kiva.org/team/friends_of_brac_uganda

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: My's Group

texts.en: Mrs. My M. is a group leader who is 1961, selected by four members whom all are made up a group loan in Trapeang Tnaot village, Takeo province. Each member will use portion of their loan for varied goal in which it can improve their living with this loan. Mrs. My M. is a farmer who owns one-hectare plot of land where she can grow crop to sell to support her family. Her problem is that her field infertile soil. So to improve production, Mrs. My M. is seeking for a loan to buy fertilizer and rest of the loan she hires farming laborers. She is widow with a child who is studying at school and helps her to do farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Oliva

texts.en:
Oliva is 40 years old and is married with four children aged 1, 6, 8 and 10 years old.

Oliva struggles in selling soft drinks, pastries (cakes) and boiled eggs. She has an experience of five years in this business and the hours of her business are from the morning hours until late in the evening.

Oliva, after realizing that her clientele was increasing day by day to the extent that she is not able to meet their demand, needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a. She really hopes that it will allow her to to expand her business a lot through adding more drinks and pastries.

With these additional goods, Oliva will hopefully earn more profits and these profits will allow her to continue taking care of her family and start saving for a better business future.

loans.use: To buy a variety of drinks and some pastries as well as boiled eggs

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama G. is divorced and has five dependents. She has not received any form of education.

Ama sells cassava, plantain, garden eggs (eggplant), kontommire (African spinach) and other foodstuffs at Elmina and has been doing this for ten years. She will use the loan to purchase additional foodstuffs to sell.

With the new earnings from her expanded business, Ama plans to save to complete a building she has already started.

loans.use: To purchase additional foodstufffs to sell

loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margret W. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs in a restaurant in Konyokonyo market. She is requesting a loan to stock more foodstuffs to cook and sell in the restaurant.  Margret is 30 years old and is divorced. She has three children, who are all in school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot, build on it, and rent it out.

loans.use: Buy more foodstuffs

loans.name: Mrs. Davy Uon Village Bank Group

texts.en: Fifteen people who live in Krang Thum village, Takeo province are made up a village bank loan. Mrs. Davy U. is a village bank president who was born in 1977, selected by the other members who will use portion of their loan for varied goals. She is a pig breeder moreover she is a rice white maker who is able earn some money to support her family. Since her business is going well she wants to expand. So to improve breeding pig, Mrs. Davy U. is asking for a loan to buy more piglets to breeding. Her husband, Mr. bonthoeurn Chhe, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family moreover he is a construction worker. She is a mother of three children, two of whom are attending in local public school, while the other is four years old.

loans.use: To buy more piglets to breeding

loans.name: Sharon

texts.en:
Sharon N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has one child, who is not in school. Sharon has a business making carry powder, which she has done for four years

To help expand her business, Sharon is requesting a loan of 150000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more papers for carry powder. Sharon hopes that the loan will help her by allowing her to increase the profit from her business. In the future, Sharon hopes to do another business.

About BRAC Uganda: This loan is administered by BRAC Uganda, a registered non-governmental organization (NGO) in Uganda that is also a part of the BRAC international network. BRAC Uganda attempts to address poverty through a holistic model, offering programs in education, health, water and sanitation, agriculture, and microfinance. BRAC Uganda’s microfinance program aims to provide the poor with easy, reliable, and efficient access to institutional financial services, and reaches over 150,000 families in Uganda. For more on BRAC Uganda, please see our partner page at http://www.kiva.org/partners/65, and join our lending team, Friends of BRAC Uganda, at http://www.kiva.org/team/friends_of_brac_uganda.

loans.use: To buy more papers for carry powder

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua E. is a widow who takes care of seven dependents. She has no formal educational background.

Efua is a fishmonger at Elmina and uses the income she generates to educate, clothe and feed her dependents. She is going to use the loan to purchase more fresh fish to smoke and sell.

With the fresh profits from her increased business, Efua plans to save to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase more fresh fish to smoke and sell

loans.name: Fayziniso

texts.ru: Ахатова Файзинисо проживает в городе Курган-Тюбе. Возраст, 50 лет. Замужем, имеет одного ребенка. Дочь занимается шитьем. Сама Файзинисо имеет среднее образование. Более 5 лет занимается торговлей на рынке. Она в основном торгует мужской одеждой. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Fayziniso A. lives the city of Qurgan-Tube. She is 50 years old, married, and has one child. Her daughter works as a seamstress. Fayziniso has a high school education. She has been selling at the market for more than five years. She primarily sells men’s wear. She is taking out a loan to increase sales.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing sales

loans.name: Kisaka

texts.en:
Kisaka S. is 24 years old and married to Rose. He supports two people in his family.

Kisaka is a farmer. He farms on his own piece of land, which he has been doing this for the past three years.

He learned about KADET through a friend who is a KADET client. This is his first loan. He plans to use 20,000 KES on harrowing, 20,000 KES on seeds, and 10,000 KES to plant 10 acres of wheat.

He hopes to use the profit he makes to expand his farming activity from small scale to commercial farming.

Kisaka's dream is to do large-scale farming and attain financial independence.

He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his goals.

loans.use: Farming expenses

loans.name: Adjouavi

texts.fr: L. Adjouavi est née le 27 Février 1961 à Allada, dans le département de l’Atlantique. Adjouavi vit depuis sa naissance au quartier Dogoudo à Allada. Mariée à HOUNTONDJI Séraphin, un maçon, Adjouavi est mère de six enfants, tous scolarisés. Seulement trois des enfants sont à la charge du couple. Adjouavi vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité, Adjouavi participe pleinement aux dépenses de la famille. Adjouavi n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Adjouavi mène comme activité la vente de l’huile de palme et de façon secondaire, des chaussures à Allada. Adjouavi exerce cette activité depuis une dizaine d’année. C’est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, mais aussi à Allada, que Adjouavi achète ses produits. Adjouavi a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, et les a tous bien remboursés. De jour en jours, la demande en produits de sa clientèle se fait de plus en plus sentir. C’est donc pour rehausser son activité par l’augmentation du stock de ses produits que Adjouavi sollicite un troisième prêt, afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. Adjouavi ambitionne dans l’avenir acquérir une parcelle et la construire.
texts.en:
Adjouavi L. was born February 27, 1961 in Allada, in the Atlantique department. She has lived all her life in the Dogoudo neighborhood of Allada. Married to Séraphin HOUNTONDJI, a mason, Adjouavi is the mother of six children, all in school. Only three of the children are in the couple’s care. Adjouavi and her husband live together with their children. Adjouavi only attended primary school. As a means of support, she runs a business in Allada selling palm oil, with a secondary trade in footwear. She has been doing this for about ten years. With the income generated by her activity, Adjouavi fully participates in meeting the family’s expenses. She gets her stocks in Cotonou, Benin's economic capital, and in Allada. Adjouavi has previously received two loans from ALIDé, both fully repaid. Customer demand for her products is growing steadily, so she is requesting a third loan to enhance her activity by increasing her stocks and better serve her customers. In the future, Adjouavi hopes to acquire a piece of land to build a house.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 5 cans of palm oil and 5 boxes of shoes

loans.name: God Help Group

texts.en:
Freeman B., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Help. He is 56 years old, is married, and has seven children who range in age from 21 to 33. He was only able to attend school through 11th grade due to lack of financial support.  

For 22 years, he has been selling charcoal in Nezoe Community Market outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollars portion of this 26,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more bags of charcoal. He describes himself as a loving person.

His goal is to improve his business and build a warehouse.

In the photo, Martha is inset at the lower right because she was absent when the group photo was taken.

loans.use: To buy charcoal.

loans.name: Abdumalik

texts.en:
A. Abdumalik is a talented entrepreneur with a successful business selling clothing and shoes for teenagers. He is not married and lives with his parents. Abdumalik started his business 15 years ago out of a desire to earn a living and meet people’s clothing needs. He sells clothes that are both popular and affordable, which helps to ensure a strong demand for his products. Abdumalik is a serious business-owner who wants his business to be the best it can be while continuing to grow and be profitable. 

One of his main goals is to have his own family and to build his own house. Abdumalik has requested a loan of $3000 USD to purchase new inventory. The change of seasons makes this a busy time of year for business-owners like Abdumalik. This loan will help him keep a good supply of inventory on hand so he can meet customer demand and make a good profit.    

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. Tajikistan has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Today, Tajikistan is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions.

Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve their agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients have the opportunity to have a viable business. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase new clothing to sell

loans.name: Noëlie

texts.fr: A. Noëlie est née le 25 Décembre 1966 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à TCHIBOZO Antonin, un enseignant, Noëlie est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés, dont trois sont à sa charge. Noëlie vit avec sa famille au quartier Dogoudo à Allada, dans le département de l’Atlantique. Les charges de la famille sont supportées de façon conjointe par Noëlie et son mari. Noëlie n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Pour assurer ses différentes charges, Noëlie mène comme activité la vente du riz, de l’huile végétale et de façon secondaire, Noëlie vend du sucre et des biscuits à Allada. C’est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, et aussi à Allada que Noëlie s’approvisionne. Noëlie est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant obtenu antérieurement trois crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Noëlie désire augmenter son capital et son chiffre d’affaire ; raison pour laquelle Noëlie sollicite un quatrième prêt pour rehausser le niveau de son activité.
texts.en:
Noëlie Aiko was born on December 25, 1966 in COutonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Antonin Tchibozo, a teacher, and is the mother of four children, all of whom go to school and three of whom are in her care. Noëlie lives with her family in the Dogoudo district in Allada, in the Atlantic Department of Benin. The spouses take care of the family expenses jointly. Noëlie attended only primary school. In order to provide for her various needs, she sells rice and vegetable oil, and, as a secondary business activity, she sells sugar and cookies in Allada. She stocks up in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, as well as in Allada. She is an old-time client of ALIDé, having obtained three loans in the past, all duly repaid. Noëlie would like to increase her business capital and her revenues, which is why she is seeking a fourth loan in order to enlarge the scope of her business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing 5 bags of rice, 5 cans of vegetable oil and 4 bags of sugar

loans.name: Shafoat

texts.en: Shafoat B. is a married mother of four children. She sells kid’s clothing in the central market of Istaravshan. She has a wide variety of merchandise combined with reasonable prices. Shafoat has been in this trade for 16 years. She is trying to do everything she can to provide for her family and give her children a decent education. That is why she wants to continue expanding her business and growing her trade by increasing the number of her vending locations. Shafoat is requesting a loan of 7500 Somoni to sustain her business and help ensure it continues to provide enough income to live on. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new goods for increasing stock

loans.name: Pariken Ole

texts.en:
Pariken Ole P. is 38 years old. He is a farmer and supports seven people in his family. His spouse is Nalamai P. and they have six school-going children. Nalamai is a housewife and she helps Pariken in his farming activity.

Pariken does wheat farming, which he has been doing for the last 13 years successfully. This will be his first loan and he is planning to buy chemicals to spray his wheat farm.

He is planning to use the anticipated profit from his farming to expand his farming activity by renting a bigger piece of land to increase his wheat production.

His hope and dream is that he will become a large-scale farmer, owning farm machinery and being financially stable to support his family.

loans.use: He is planning to buy chemicals to spray his wheat farm

loans.name: With God All Things Are Possible Group

texts.en:
M. S., is the leader of a group of five borrowers called With God All Things Are Possible. He is 34 years old, married and has three children who range from 5 to 12 years old. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to lack of financial support.  

For 13 years, he has been selling men's footwear such as sneakers, sandals, slippers, shoes, etc., in Redlight Market outside Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 6,000-Liberian-Dollar portion of this 30,000-Liberian-Dollar group loan to buy more sneakers, sandals, slippers, shoes, etc. He describes himself as a very quiet person.

His dream is to improve his business and build a house. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Sonnie M. is holding the sign in the middle of the group.

loans.use: To buy more sneakers, sandals, slippers, shoes, etc.

loans.name: Véronique

texts.fr: Née en Janvier 1963 à Allada dans le département de l’Atlantique, H. Véronique vit depuis trente sept ans au quartier Dogoudo à Allada. Véronique est mariée à GBOGLI François, un mécanicien, et est mère de cinq enfants dont certains sont scolarisés. Parmi les enfants, trois seulement sont à la charge du couple. Véronique vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges familiales. N’ayant pas été à l’école, Véronique mène comme activité depuis une vingtaine d’année, la vente de l’huile de palme à Allada. Véronique s’approvisionne dans les villages d’Allada. C’est la troisième fois que Véronique sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un crédit, en vue d’augmenter davantage le stock de ses produits et d’élargir son champ d’activité.
texts.en:
Born in January 1963 in Allada in Benin’s Atlantique Department, Véronique H. has lived for 37 years in the Dogoudo neighborhood of Allada. She is married to François Gbogli, a mechanic, and has five children, some of whom are in school. Only three of the children are currently in the couple’s care. Véronique lives with her husband and children. The couple shares the family’s expenses. Never having been to school, Véronique has been selling palm oil for 20 years in Allada. She buys her supplies in the villages of Allada. This is the third time that Véronique is requesting a loan through ALIDé, with the goal of increasing her inventory and widening the scope of her business.

Translated from French by Rachel Braff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 13 cans of palm oil.

loans.name: Komi Mokpokpo

texts.en: Mr. Komi A. is 36 years old and married to a merchant in Lomé, Togo. He’s been the proprietor of his own internet café since 2008 and his business is growing. He already has two employees. Komi is now taking his second loan from WAGES of 500,000 CFA to help him expand his business. He will purchase two computers and 5 desks to house to serve his growing number of clients.

loans.use: To purchase two computers and 5 desks

loans.name: Anbar

texts.en:
J. Anbar is 53 years old. She and her husband have raised two children who are already married and living independently. Anbar has been selling jewellery for almost 18 years. As a rule she works in the store, however she also has a trading place in the local market. Anbar sells jewellery items of an oriental national style. She has her customers and clients who sell their jewellery to her. People trust Anbar, knowing that she is very honest when assessing the prices and quality. Anbar's business is the main source of income for her family. She has been working with IMON for almost two years. She has proved herself as an honest and reliable borrower. Today she requests $1500 US Dollars. For the loan Anbar plans to purchase new items of jewellery like earrings, rings and bracelets of the oriental style. She thanks all for support and promises to pay the loan in time.

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase jewellery to sell.

loans.name: Eya

texts.en: Mme. Eya A. is 38 years old and living in Lomé, Togo. She is a widow with one child. Since 1995 she’s been working at the Adidogomé Market in Lomé where she sells pagnes, a traditional Togolese wax-printed cloth, and other fabrics. She is also a seamstress who makes clothing from the fabrics she sells. As an experienced entrepreneur, she is continuously invested in strengthening and expanding her business. She is taking her third loan from WAGES of 350,000 CFA in order to purchase 25 rolls of fabric.

loans.use: To purchase pagnes and other cloth

loans.name: Nodira

texts.en:
M. Nodira is 36 years old. She is married with two children. Nodira is running her own business to help her husband to support the family. She is selling jewellery. Nodira has been in this business for more than 12 years. Today Nodira requests 7500 Somoni to purchase new items of jewelry like earrings, rings, bracelets, and chains in order to increase the range of goods she sells. This is the eleventh loan Nodira has taken out and she promises to observe all the procedures concerning the payment of the loan as she has done with previous loans. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy more jewellery to sell.

loans.name: Marima Ole

texts.en:
Marima Ole E. is 38 years old. He is a farmer and supports five people in his family. His wife is Reson YE. and they have four children aged 12, 8, 7 and 6. Reson is a house wife and she helps her husband with the farm.

Marima farms wheat, which he has been doing successfully for the last ten years. This will be his first loan and he is planning to buy chemicals to spray his wheat farm.

He is planning to use the anticipated profit from his farming to expand his farming activity, by hiring a bigger piece of land to increase his wheat production.

His hope and dream is that he will become a large scale farmer, owning a bigger piece of land, and be financially stable enough to support his family.

loans.use: To buy chemicals for his farm

loans.name: Emilienne

texts.fr: M. Emilienne est née le 30 Juin 1972 à Allada, dans le département de l’Atlantique. Mariée à AHOUISSOUSSI Alain, un chauffeur, Emilienne est mère de cinq enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Emilienne vit depuis dix sept ans au quartier Dogoudo à Allada, avec sa famille. Les charges de la famille sont supportées par Emilienne et son mari. Emilienne n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Emilienne prépare et vend de la nourriture (riz, pâte de maïs et de cossette d’igname, accompagnés de diverses sauces) à Allada. Emilienne  achète ses produits dans les marchés d’Allada. Emilienne mène cette activité depuis huit ans et a déjà bénéficié de trois crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés auprès de ALIDé. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et d’augmenter le volume de ses ventes, pour se faire plus de revenus, Emilienne sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Emilienne ambitionne plus tard acquérir sa propre parcelle.
texts.en:
M. Emilienne was born on June 30, 1972 in Allada, in Atlantique county. She is married to AHOUISSOUSSI Alain, a chauffeur, and is a mother of five children, some of whom are in school. Emilienne has been living with her family in the Dogoudo district in Allada for seventeen years. Family expenses are covered by her and her husband. Emilienne did not attend school. To support herself, she makes and sells food (rice, cornmeal mash, and yam chips served with various sauces) in Allada. She purchases her supplies at Allada markets. She has been in this business for eight years and has already benefited from three loans, which have all been repaid to ALIDé. With the goal of bolstering her business and increasing her sales volume, so as to make more revenues, Emilienne is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé. Her ambition is to acquire her own plot of land later on.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying 2 sacks of rice, 1 sack of yam chips, 1 sack of corn, 1 container of oil, and some condiments

loans.name: Saodat

texts.en: Saodat R. is 47 years old. She is married and has a daughter. For more than 20 years, Saodat has had her own business. She embroiders the national skull-cap for men and women. Saodat produces various types of the national skull-cap, so she has many clients and usually there are many orders. Her daughter helps her with the business. Saodat sells the skull-caps to her own customers, who are always in expectation of the new goods. Thus her business is stable, allowing Saodat to contribute significant income into the family budget. Today, Saodat requests 7500 Somoni. The loan is required for purchasing the fabrics for embroidering the national skull-cap. Saodat thanks all supporting her and promises to pay the loan on time. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a being key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing fabrics for embroidering the national skull-cap

loans.name: Ilhomjon

texts.en: Ilhomjon U. is a young clothing merchant from Istaravshan, Tajikistan. He started his small business when he was in his late teens and gradually, though much hard work, he has been able to develop it into quite a successful enterprise. Ilhomjon has the qualities it takes to succeed as an entrepreneur. Goal-oriented, hard-working and punctual, he is a natural businessman. Funding from IMON International has been instrumental in helping Ilhomjon build his business. His first loan was for $1,500 and since that time, he has benefited from one additional loan while establishing a great credit history. He has requested a loan of $2,000 to add to his available working capital. The ability to purchase large quantities of inventory in bulk saves time and expense for merchants such as Ilhomjon. He appreciates the availability of funding through IMON International. It allows him to take advantage of good opportunities and focus on growing his business so that he is able to adequately provide for himself and his family. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a being key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new clothing for selling

loans.name: Fidèle

texts.fr: S. Fidèle est née le 23 Novembre 1973 à Allada, dans le département de l’Atlantique. Fidèle est une veuve et mère de six enfants, tous scolarisés, dont trois restent à sa charge. Depuis une dizaine d’année, Fidèle vit avec ses enfants au quartier Dogoudo à Allada. Fidèle assure seule les différentes charges de la maison. Pour y faire face, Fidèle vend des œufs frais et de façon secondaire, de l’oignon au marché de Allada. Fidèle s’approvisionne dans les villages de Allada. Fidèle exerce cette activité depuis cinq ans et a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a tous bien remboursés. Dans le but d’agrandir son activité et de mieux répondre à la demande nombreuse de sa clientèle, Fidèle sollicite auprès de ALIDé un troisième prêt.
texts.en:
S. Fidèle was born on November 23, 1973 in Allada, in Atlantique county. She is a widow and the mother of six children, who have all had schooling. Three of the children remain in her care. For a dozen years, she has been living with her children in the Dogoudo district in Allada. By herself, she ensures that the different household expenses are covered. To cope, Fidèle sells fresh eggs, and secondarily she sells onions, at the Allada market. She gets her supplies from Allada villages. She has been in this business for five years and has already had two loans from ALIDé that she repaid. With the goal of expanding her business and responding better to the numerous demands of her customers, Fidèle is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying 60 trays of fresh eggs

loans.name: Group Of Faith

texts.en:
Mark S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Group of Faith. He is 31 years old, single and has one child who is 6 years old. He is a sophomore university student.  

For 13 years, he has been selling tablets (medication) on the street in the Redlight Market outside Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 6,000-Liberian-Dollar portion of this 30,000-Liberian-Dollars group loan to buy more tablets (medication). He describes himself as an easy-going person.

His goal is to grow his business and build a pharmacy.

loans.use: To buy more tablets (medication)

loans.name: Inobat

texts.en: Inobat is a married mother of five children. Her kids’ clothing sales business has been a valuable source of income for her and her family over the past 10 years that she’s been in business. In a typical month, Inobat makes about $200 in profit from the business. Inobat is a hardworking, polite and communicative entrepreneur. She has an attitude of service and loves being able to help her clients with their clothing needs. Inobat has requested a loan of 4,000 Somoni to purchase new inventory. This loan will help her to continue developing her business and to provide a good income for her family. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a being key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new clothing for kids for the summer season

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more used clothes

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Bulenga in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has a child who is not in school. Florence has owned a beauty salon for one year. To help expand her business, Florence is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda, a Kiva partner. The loan will be used to buy more materials for the beauty salon. Florence hopes that the loan will help her by allowing her to expand her business. In the future, Florence hopes to pay school fees for her child and help her family. About BRAC Uganda: This loan is administered by BRAC Uganda, a registered non-governmental organization (NGO) in Uganda that is also a part of the BRAC international network. BRAC Uganda attempts to address poverty through a holistic model, offering programs in education, health, water and sanitation, agriculture, and microfinance. BRAC Uganda’s microfinance program aims to provide the poor with easy, reliable and efficient access to institutional financial services, and reaches over 150,000 families in Uganda. For more on BRAC Uganda, please see our partner page at http://www.kiva.org/partners/65, and join our lending team, Friends of BRAC Uganda, at http://www.kiva.org/team/friends_of_brac_uganda

loans.use: To add more materials for the beauty salon

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.en:
A. Mahbuba is 49 years old. She is married and the mother of two children. Since she was very young Mahbuba worked on a small farm, and now, along with her children she works cultivating wheat, corn, and vegetables. When their crop comes in they transport it to the capital for sale. This activity has helped to pay for the expenses of her family and the education of her children. 

Today she needs a loan for preparing his land for upcoming season. With this desire in mind she asks your consideration to receive them in your kind heart. She requests $1000 USD. Mahbuba wants to thank everyone for supporting her and promises to repay the loan in time.    

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Karen

texts.en:
Karen T. was born in Yerevan in 1974. Karen is married and lives with his wife and little son in Ijevan city. His wife doesn't work: she takes care of their child. 

Since 1998 Karen has been running a food shop, where he sells fruits and vegetables, sausages, beverages, ice cream, and other foods. With profit from his business Karen solves his young family's needs, and has bought some furniture and computer equipment for his home.

Karen is requesting a loan of 470,000 AMD loan to buy watermelons, melons, cherries, plums, etc. to sell in his shop.

loans.use: To buy watermelons, melons, cherries, plums, etc. for his shop

loans.name: Our God Is Good. Group

texts.en:
Isaac H., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Our God Is Good.

He is 35 years old, single, and has one child who is 10 years old. He was only able to attend school through 9th grade due to financial difficulty.   

For 10 years, he has been operating a barber shop in Redlight Market outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 10,000 LRD portion of this 38,000 LRD group loan to buy more barber shop products such as a hair dryer, shampoo, oil shine and gel. 

He describes himself as a devoted family man. His dream is to grow his business and build a shop.

loans.use: To buy more barber shop products such as shampoo, oil shine, gel, etc.

loans.name: Faith In God Group

texts.en:
Emmanuel K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Faith In God. He is 30 years old, married, and has two children between 5 and 7 years old. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial constraints.   

For seven years, he has been selling men's footwear such as shoes, sneakers and sandals in Redlight Market outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 6,000 LRD portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more men's footwear to sell, including shoes, sneakers and sandals. He describes himself as an earnest person.

His dream is to improve his business and build a store.

loans.use: To buy more men's footwear to sell

loans.name: Fiona

texts.en:
Fiona N. is 17 years old and lives in the town of Bulenga in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is single and has one child, who is not yet in school.  

Fiona has a business of selling food, which she has had for one year. 

To help expand her business, Fiona is requesting a loan of 150,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to buy more food to sell.  Fiona hopes that the loan will help her by allowing her to increase her capital.  In the future, Fiona hopes to go back to her studies. 

About BRAC Uganda:  This loan is administered by BRAC Uganda, a registered non-governmental organization (NGO) in Uganda that is also a part of the BRAC international network.  BRAC Uganda attempts to address poverty through a holistic model, offering programs in education, health, water & sanitation, agriculture and micro-finance. BRAC Uganda’s micro-finance program aims to provide the poor with easy, reliable, and efficient access to institutional financial services, and reaches over 150,000 families in Uganda.  For more on BRAC Uganda, please see our partner page at http://www.kiva.org/partners/65, and join our lending team, Friends of BRAC Uganda, at http://www.kiva.org/team/friends_of_brac_uganda

loans.use: To buy more food to sell

loans.name: Loice

texts.en:
Loice is 48 years old. She is married and has one 25-year-old child who is currently attending school. She has been practicing mixed farming for over 20 years in Kisii town, Western Kenya. Her farm produces maize, milk, tea and bananas which she sells to the local market. She also earns income from the sale of secondhand clothes and bricks.

Her primary challenges have been the high cost of transportation and the fluctuation in the prices of commodities.

Loice has requested this loan of 60,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to expand her cereal business. The extra income from this loan will help her educate her child. She would like to expand her dairy business in the future.

She appreciates the good relationship between herself and Juhudi and hopes for the best through the partnership.

loans.use: To expand her cereal business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy new wedding dresses to sell.

loans.name: Kerubo

texts.en:
Kerubo is 55 years old. She is married and has been blessed with eight children between the ages of 14 and 30. Three of the children attend school.

She is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya, where she has been practicing mixed farming for over twenty years. Her farm produces maize, beans, bananas, vegetables and milk which she sells to the local market. She faces the challenges of high cost of farm supplies, the fluctuating prices of her products and her lack of knowledge about disease and pest control.

She has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 50,000 KES to expand her cereal business. The extra income from this loan will help pay school fees for her children and build a house. She plans to open a big cereal bank in a more strategic place in the future.

She appreciates the partnership with Juhudi Kilimo and acknowledges the fact that she has been able to educate her children with the profits from this business.

loans.use: To expand her cereal business.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is 63 years old. He is married and has been blessed with eight children who are between the ages of 12 and 37. Three of the children attend school.

Richard is a dairy farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been been farming for the last thirty-eight years and has four employees. He sells his milk to Brookside Company. He is also a cash crop farmer and sells his tea to the local market. He also operates a retail shop in the same area.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 60,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. He says that the extra income from this loan will help pay school fees for his children and help with other personal expenses. In the future, he would like to improve his sources of income and purchase a pickup truck.

He is happy with the products offered by Juhudi but would like the amount of loan to be reviewed and reduce the amount of savings required as collateral.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow..

loans.name: Firuza

texts.ru: Камолова Фируза проживает в городе Курган-Тюбе. Возраст, 22 года. Не замужем. Имеет среднее образование. Занимается торговлей. Она продает мужcкую и женскую обувь в центральном рынке города. Имеет хороший опыт в этой сфере. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара. На полученную прибыль хочет устроить свадьбу своего брата.
texts.en:
Firuza K. lives the city of Qurgan-Tube. She is 22 years old and single. She has a high school education. She works in sales. She sells male and female footwear in the city’s central market. She has experience in this work. She is taking out a loan to increase the variety of goods she sells. With her profits, she wants to pay for her brother’s wedding.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing inventory

loans.name: Johana

texts.en:
Johana is a dairy farmer from the town of Litein in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been farming for ten years and has employed two people from his community. He sells his milk to Kenya Cooperative Creameries. He is also a cash crop farmer and sells his tea to the local market. 

Johana is 41 years old. He is married and has four children who are all attending school.

Johana has a clean record with Juhudi Kilimo after he successfully completed his previous two loans of 45,000 KES and 60,000 KES. He has requested this loan of 80,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. He says that the extra income from this loan will go towards the education of his children.

In the future, he would like to own at least three quality dairy cows. He is grateful to Juhudi for the support given.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Alinhinkira Womens Association-Jinja Group

texts.en:
In every difficult situation, there is always the need for one to remain philosophical. Succumbing to self pity and resentment has always been most young people’s weak point. This weakness in character is what 35-year-old N. Joy has invariably steered clear of in the last four years as she operates her metal fabrication shop business in Ivunamba-Jinja. 

She says her strongest personal attributes are being unwavering and in having self drive. She is a joyful married lady with four school going children. She has been driving a roaring trade in her business, going by the $80 her business generates for her in a month as profits. 

With this loan she wants to buy more metal to improve her metal fabrication business. She says she will be able to fabricate more items such as metal chairs.

loans.use: Buying more metal for fabricating household items such as metal chairs

loans.name: Prosperity. Group

texts.en:
Delkontee M. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Prosperity. In the photo she is holding the sign, She is 42 years old, married and has two children who range from 9 to 15 years old.  Delkontee was only able to attend school through the 12th grade due to lack of financial support.  For 16 years, she has been selling coconuts in Redlight Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 12,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 60,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more coconuts. She describes herself as easy-going. Her dream is to expand her business and educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more coconuts to sell

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi A. cooks rice and serves it with tomato sauce at Elmina. The loan she is expecting will be used to buy extra bags of rice to cook and also to sell some raw. She wishes to use the new profits from her business to save to build a shop for her business.

Esi has received junior high education. She is married to a steel bender and has three children. She provides assistance by contributing to the well-being of her family.

loans.use: To buy extra bags of rice to cook and to sell

loans.name: Wanyange Tusubiira Womens Group-Jinja

texts.en:
For three and a half years, 41 year old Harriet W. has operated her charcoal business in Wanyange-Jinja.  This business combined with her commercial motorcycle business has been providing all the financial ways and means on which she and her family have been surviving. Being that she is widowed, living only by her wits was unacceptable. Harriet originally started work in a trade reserved for men and that is timber cutting. 

Today, this mother of four school aged children earns 50,000 shillings a week with her business. With proceeds from this loan, she says she wants to purchase more bags of charcoal that she will later resell.

loans.use: The purchase of more bags of charcoal for resell

loans.name: Mathew

texts.en:
Mathew (pictured next to his fish ponds) is 65 years old. He is married and has 6 children between the ages of 24 and 39. Two of the children are attending school. He is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya. He has been farming for over 30 years and has employed one farm-hand. His farm produces maize, tea, beans, bananas, milk, fish and nappier grass which he sells to the local market. He faces the challenge of the high prices of farm material, lack of enough feed for the fish and poor prices for his products.

Mathew has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for KES.60,000 to purchase a dairy cow. He says that this loan will enable him to expand his dairy activities and earn him income that will help him pay school fees for his children in college.

In the future, he would like to expand his dairy business and supply his milk in wholesale to other retailers. He says that through Juhudi Kilimo, he has been able to grow and really appreciates the support.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 51 years old. She is married with 4 children between the ages of 10 and 30. Two of the children are currently attending school. She has been farming for over 10 years in Kisii town, Western Kenya. Her farm produces maize, tea, bananas, vegetables, milk and nappier grass which she sells locally. Her primary challenges have been lack of enough animal feed, poor weather patterns and poor prices for her commodities.

Agnes has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of KES.50,000 to purchase a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will enable her to educate her children and expand her business. She will also be able to provide enough food for her family.

In  the future, Agnes would like to expand her dairy farming by acquiring 5 more dairy cows. She appeals for more help from Juhudi and appreciates the support rendered so far.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Mwino Akuwa-Jinja Group

texts.en:
32 year old  Judith E. began her 3 year old retail business in Mpumudde-Jinja with her own savings. She was started in the bakery business but in the course of time, she changed businesses. She has established a niche for herself in her local area and as a result her clientele (who are mostly the local community members), are now accustomed to her good humored nature. Judith has a good reputation and has made a favorable impression on most of her customers.

 In a week, she makes 120,000 shillings out of her retail enterprise. With additional profits from her commercial motorcycle and taxi businesses, she earns a good profit at the end of every week. With this loan, she wants to purchase more bags of sugar, salt and utensils for her shop. She reckons she will resell this and strengthen her profit base.

loans.use: The purchase of more retail items such as sugar, salt and sugar for resell

loans.name: Oripha

texts.en:
Oripha is 48 years old. She is a widowed mother of 2 children, ages 12 and 16, with both children attending school. She has been operating her mixed farm for 10 years in Kisii town, Western Kenya. She solely depends on the income from her farming activities to cater for the needs of her family.

Her biggest challenges have been lack of animal feeds, natural calamities and diseases, and the high competition in the market which affect her production.

Oripha has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of KES. 60,000 to purchase a water tank for collecting water for her dairy cows. She believes that this water tank will help increase her production. 

In the future, she hopes to purchase a quality dairy cow that will produce 60 litres of milk daily. She is grateful to Juhudi for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase a water tank.

loans.name: Umed

texts.ru: Кузибаев Умед проживает в районе А. Джоми. Возраст, 39 лет. Женат, детей не имеет. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Умед имеет высшее образование, экономист. По профессии работал 2 года. Сейчас он занимается торговлей на рынке. Он в основном продает стройматериалы. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 4 года. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Umed K. lives in Abdurahmon Jomi. He is 39 years old, married, and has no children. His wife is a housewife. Umed has a higher education as an economist. He worked in his trade for two years. Now he works trading in the market. He sells building materials. He has been doing this work for four years. He is taking out a loan to increase his sales.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing sales

loans.name: Olpher

texts.en:
Olpher is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya where she has been farming for 18 years. Her farm produces maize, beans, vegetables, eggs, tea, bananas and milk which she sells to the local market. Her major challenges have been lack of enough money to buy chicken feed, pests and diseases which affect her poultry and the poor weather patterns that affects her produce.

Olpher has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of KES.50,000 to expand her poultry project by purchasing 300 chicks from Kenchick Company. She says the extra income from this loan will enable her to educate her children and feed them well.

Olpher is 38 years old, married and blessed with 5 children between the ages of 8 and 25. Four of her children are attending school. In future, she plans to open a big retail shop in Ogembo town and be the biggest supplier of eggs in the town and other communities as well.

loans.use: To expand her poultry project.

loans.name: Balinaki Development Group-Jinja

texts.en: 39 year old Betty N. is now 4 and a half years into her agro produce sells business in Lukolo market-Mukono. Her bearing a hand in this business is as a result of the encouragement of her erstwhile husband. She was previously a teacher.  Betty is a divorcee with 2 children. In her business, which she operates at the rather busy Lukolo market, she has mostly been selling maize, beans and sugar cane. It’s mostly the local rank and file who are her dependable clients. In a week, this steadfastly hardworking lady makes 40,000 shillings as profit. She is also able to supplement on her profits through her pay phone services. With this loan, Betty wants to purchase a bike to help her workers easily transport her produce to her distant customers. Part of the loan will be put into buying coffee seedlings that she later intends to plant.

loans.use: The purchase of a bike to transport her produce to sell and also buy coffee seedlings

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is 44 years old. She is married and has been blessed with 4 children, ages ranging from 19 and 28. Her youngest child is currently attending school. 

Nancy has been farming for the last 3 years in Kisii town, Western Kenya. Her farm produces maize and groundnuts which she sells to the local market. She also owns and earns income from her rental houses in the same area. Her major challenges have been lack of enough capital and seasonal changes which affects her produce.

She has requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo of KES.45,000 to purchase and feed a dairy cow. She says that she will have enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The extra income from this loan will enable her to send her child to college.

She says that Juhudi should increase the amount of first loans and is grateful to Juhudi for supporting farmers.

loans.use: To purchase and feed a dairy cow.

loans.name: Priska

texts.en:
Priska is 60 years old. She is a widowed mother of 7 children. Two of her children are still attending school. She has been practicing mixed farming for over 20 years and has employed one farm-hand. Her main products are maize, beans, coffee, milk, millet and vegetables which she sells to the local market.

Priska has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of KES.40,000 to expand her cereal business. This loan will enable her to provide enough food for her grandchildren and the extra income will help her educate her children. She faces the challenges of poor weather patterns, lack of proper market for her commodities and the high cost of farm materials.

She plans to stock more cereals for sale and acquire another dairy cow in the future. She is equally grateful to Juhudi for the support and appreciates the help it has given her so far.

loans.use: To expand her cereal business.

loans.name: Varnette Venture #4 Group

texts.en:
Annie O. (who is holding the sign) is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Varnette Venture #4. She is 42 years old, married and has four children who range from 1 to 14 years old. She was only able to attend school through 11th grade due to a lack of financial support. Annie cares for one sibling.

For 3 years, she has been operating a mini restaurant in Redlight Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more cooking oil, fish, meat, rice etc. She describes herself as a caring mother. Her goal is to improve her business, build a house and continue to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more cooking oil, fish, meat, rice etc.

loans.name: Ezekiel

texts.en:
Ezekiel is a farmer from the town of Kisii in Western Kenya. He has been farming for over 20 years and has employed one farm-hand. His products are maize, bananas, beans, milk and tea which he sells to other retailers. He also makes and sells bricks to the local market.

Ezekiel is 48 years old. He is married with 6 children between the ages of 14 and 27. Two of the children are currently attending school.

He has requested this second loan from Juhudi Kilimo of KES 60,000 to purchase a dairy cow. He says that this dairy cow will produce enough milk to improve the nutrition of the family and earn income from the sale of milk. This income will enable him to educate his children and provide for the basic needs of the family.

His main challenges have been lack of technical knowledge on disease and pest control, lack of storage facilities and proper markets for his products. He hopes, however, to open a retail shop and sell his cereals in wholesale.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Ekirirwa Eira Womens's Group-Jinja

texts.en:
In kyanagwa-Jinja is where one will locate 38 year old N. Nubu’s tailoring business. Her track record in this business stretches to a time frame of 9 years.

Whilst many people grumble about the unraveling of Uganda’s textile industry, being that Ugandans are now more than ever inclined to buy second hand clothing, she has not wavered an inch in her determination to make her business a success.

For this married mother of 4 who, as she recounts, began with a vegetable selling business, there has been a relative turn in people’s preferences, especially from her vantage point. In a week, her business makes her profits that amount to 45,000 shillings.  She also runs a poultry business.

With this loan, she wants to buy more rolls of textile material to make clothing.

loans.use: The purchase of more rolls of textile material

loans.name: Varnette Venture #1 Group

texts.en:
Eva G., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Varnette Venture #1.  She is 44 years old, widowed and has six children who range from 10 to 26 years old. She was only able to attend school through 10th grade due to financial constraints. She also cares for 4 siblings.

For 7 years, she has been selling used clothes in Redlight Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more bags of used clothes. She describes herself as an earnest person.

Her goal is to expand her business and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more bags of used clothes

loans.name: Varnette Venture #2 Group

texts.en:
Bendu B.  is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Varnette Venture #2. She is 36 years old, married and has three children who range from 4 to 18 years old. Bendu  is holding the sign in the photo. She is a college student and also cares for two siblings.

For 4 years, she has been selling water and soft drinks in Redlight Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more sacks of water and more crates of soft drink.

She describes herself as a good mother. Her goal is to improve her business and continue to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of water and more crates of soft drink

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Bishnu

texts.en:
This is 30 year-old Bishnu D..  She is married and has 3 children aged 12, 6, and 4 months.  In 2005, she established  her agirculture business.  Working 7 days a week and 8 hours a day, she supports her family.  

She has already received and successfully repaid 3 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to purchase vegetable seeds and materials.  In the future, Bishnu plans to send her children to school.  She thanks you for your support.

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural.  Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land.  Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet.  With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer.  With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market.  Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year. 

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007.  Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women.  In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.  For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates:
 BPW Partner Page     Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team"

loans.use: vegeatable farming

loans.name: Charles

texts.fr: N. Charles est un homme de 40 ans, il est née en district Kicukiro en ville de Kigali capital du Rwanda, son niveau d’étude est primaire.  Il est commençant de détail en boutique. Il contracte un prêt pour acheter des  savons, sucre et du sel pour augmenter  son capital et sa capacité de ventes en vue de gagner tous les clients de son quartier. Il a ouvert un compte dans Amasezerano Community Banking   depuis 2007, avec ce prêt il veut augmenter les épargnes afin de réhabiliter  sa maison d’habitation, l’augmentation de son chiffre d’affaires  lui permettra de payer le minerval pour ses enfants et améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille et avoir fait un gros magasin  dans l’avenir.
texts.en:
Charles N. is a 40-year-old man, born in the Kicukiro district in Kigali, the Rwandan capital. He has a primary school education and is beginning to sell retail in a store. He is requesting a loan to buy soaps, sugar, and salt to increase his capital and his selling capacity in order to attract all the potential customers in the neighborhood.
